Carmen previously lived with her parents but she has worked hard to save enough money to buy a small plot on which to build a home for her son. This, Carmen's third loan with Agrocapital, will pay to finish construction of the home. Carmen has no other debts and repaid her previous loans promptly.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Carmen es una mamá soltera de 31 años de edad, su hijito tiene 10 años. Debido a que ella es el sustento de su familia, se esforzo para alcanzar el grado de técnico medio, actualmente trabaja desde hace cuatro años en un proyecto Solidario de la Sociedad Salesiana MUYURINA, desempeñandose como administradora del programa educativo, su trabajo demanda gran parte de su tiempo ya que tiene que viajar a las zonas rurales para dar asistencia y capacitación a las personas que se dedican a la agricultura. Antes de conseguir ahorrar dinero para comprar un pequeño lote, Carmen vivía con sus papás, peo debido al empeño que puso en su trabajo y al apoyo de su familia logró conseguir construir su casita donde dará un techo seguro a su hijito. La presente solicitud es para finalizar la construcción de su vivienda, debido a que le falto dinero. Carmen actualmente no tiene deudas en otras instituciones y este crédito es el tercero con nuestra Institución, tiempo en el cual demostró tener pagos puntuales y oportunos.

loans.use: To complete construction of a home.

loans.name: Valasi

texts.en: Ms Valasi is a young lady of twenty four years of age; she has just finished school but has no job. She decided to take frying pancakes as her business, which will be easy to achieve as it was one of her experiences from her home economics class in school. She used all her 1st loan of $300 to buy the ingredients needed for this particular business and she hopes that this will help her to get some money for her personal needs and for paying her weekly repayments. She is very happy with the program and wishes to get another loan to improve her business.

loans.use: Buy ingredients for the business

loans.name: David

texts.es:
David is a young, single man who lives with his parents. He drives a number 54 bus in Santa Cruz, a busy route which passes by the major marketplaces. He has been driving a bus for five years and uses the income to help support his family. Transportation in Santa Cruz is a very competitive business but with the city growing as rapidly as it is there will always be good demand for busdrivers. This loan will pay for repairs to the bus, which sees almost constant use. David does not have a credit history but our study of his business shows he will be able to repay the loan.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

David es una persona joven, soltera, que actualmente vive en la casa de sus padres. David trabaja como chofer de un micro de la línea número 54 en la ciudad de Santa Cruz, la ruta de esta línea es bastante demandada por los pasajeros ya que pasa por todos los mercados importantes de la ciudad. David cuenta con una experiencia de 5 años como conductor de micro, los ingresos que percibe por esta actividad le permiten ayudar a su familia en los diferentes gastos de la misma. Indudablemente existe bastante competencia en este rubro especialmente en Santa Cruz que es una ciudad que en los últimos tiempos ha crecido de una manera exorbitante, pero es gracias a este crecimiento que el rubro de transporte local de pasajeros siempre tendrá buena demanda. La presente solicitud es para refacciones del micro ya que con el constante uso que se le da al mismo requiere de una revisión permanente. El cliente no tiene mucha experiencia crediticia, pero de acuerdo a la evaluación efectuada al mismo cuenta con la capacidad de pagar el crédito.

loans.use: To repair a bus.

loans.name: Savali

texts.en: Savali is a thirty-one year old woman with six kids. She has supported her family single-handedly with  this business. She makes money with the business, but not enough to cover all of her needs, especially those of her children. That’s why she has applied for her 1st loan of $300 - to buy more meat in order to get more profit. She’s planning that her next loan will be used to cover her children’s school fees for the whole year so that it will be easier for her to focus on her business.

loans.use: Buying meat for her business

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Ms Rosalina is a young, 24-year old lady  with two children. She didn’t finish school due to the lack of financial support from her parents, so she is now staying home and started her pancakes and pork buns business to provide for her family, especially her kids. She said she didn’t want her kids to follow in her footsteps and have the same problem she had while she was in school. So her $300 loan was used to buy the ingredients needed for her business, which is the only source of income she can get. She believes that her next loan will be used to repair their house to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: Buying ingredients for her business

loans.name: Ruta

texts.en: Mrs T. is a fifty-three-year-old woman with seven children. She has been very interested in making and cooking barbeque foods since she was a teenager, and that’s why she took it as her business and used her $300 loan to buy the ingredients. She believes that even though it is a very hard business, she is strong enough to make it and she thinks she will get more profits from it. She is looking forward to another loan to buy a gas oven which is much easier and saves time because she will not have to collect firewood or provide charcoal as with her current charcoal oven. She will be very happy to stay for a long time in the loan programme

loans.use: Buying meats for the Barbeque

loans.name: Tofu

texts.en: Tofu is married with two children. Shestays at home and does not have a job, but she is very good at making pork buns and she spent all of her first $300 loan to buy the most needed ingredients for her business doing these. She is planning to extend her business with her next loan, adding German buns, donuts and pies, because she is good at making them. She believes that without the help she got from the SPBD program, she would not have been able to do it, and she will be happy to stay for a long time in the programme.

loans.use: Buying ingredients for the business

loans.name: Feiloaiga

texts.en: Ms P. is a widowed lady of sixty three years of age with two kids. Even though she is old, she is still an active woman in the family because there is no father to support her. She is a very good tailor; she started doing this particular business when she was twenty five years old, and so far she wants to continue with her talent. That’s why she has applied for her $300 loan just to maintain the good supplies of her business and to hold on to her usual clients. She is wanting to get another extra loan to build a special place for her business.

loans.use: Buy materials needed for the business

loans.name: Tafaoga

texts.en: Tafaoga is 29 years old, married, and has four children. She was given a loan of $300 before to purchase some stocks to start a small shop. Although she has started her business, she still does not feel confident. She has applied for a second loan of $500, to purchase a building for her shop, which is currently run out of her home. The rest of the loan will be used to purchase goods and supplies for her store. She is currently extremely happy with her business, and hopes to improve her future with this loan.

loans.use: Re-stock

loans.name: Isa

texts.en: Mrs. T. is 59 years old, married, and has ten children. All her life, Mrs. T. has raised her children up with her own two hands, and no other source of financial support. This is why she has worked extremely hard to keep her business and continue the supply of financial support for her family’s needs. She will in turn use her monetary gain to fund her children’s education. The loan she is applying for is to repair the roof of their house to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Provide materials & buy ingredients for the fast foods stall.

loans.name: Vinesa

texts.en: Ms. M. is a 50-year old married woman with seven children. She likes to do her business because she knows she can get more profit from it. She works very hard in order to get more profit to raise her seven kids and satisfy the family needs. She believes that this kind of business is not worth it if the person running it is not very active. She is also aiming for another loan to extend the shop and add the necessary stocks such as junk foods, beer and cigarettes. She is very happy with the programme and wishes to stay long in it, as this is the only financial support for her business.

loans.use: Re-stock

loans.name: Anarosa

texts.en: Anarosa is 32 years old has three children. She was unemployed until she decided to start her own barbeque business to provide for her family. She enjoys running her own business, because of her skill at cooking and her interest in cuisine. Her first loan of $300 was spent on purchasing the meats needed to run her business. She would like another loan to purchase a gas oven to replace her old charcoal cooker, which would make serving her clients much easier. She is extremely appreciative of the aid she has received that helped her begin her own business.

loans.use: Buying meats for the business.

loans.name: Teu

texts.en: Teu F. is 65 years old, and has five children. She is currently supporting her family and herself through the earnings from her business and her pension. Most of her children have now left and have started their own families, but she and her husband are still together. Teu has used a previous loan of $300 to lift her business off the ground and begin selling pancakes. Teu enjoys the prospect of working once more, and wishes to be active, not only as a mother and wife, but also as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: Buying ingredients needed for the business.

loans.name: Aofialefagailaua

texts.en: Aofialefagailaua S. is married, and has four children. She is extremely interested in making and printing elei materials. She gained the experience from a village seminar. Even though she had the knowledge, she did not have enough money to begin her business. As a result, she applied for a loan of $300, which enabled her to purchase the necessary equipment. She is extremely happy for any financial aid she has enjoyed, and is grateful for the opportunity she was given.

loans.use: Provide materials and buy paints

loans.name: Faaluaumeke

texts.en: Faaluaumeke is a married twenty six year old with two children. She is starting a barbecue as her running business because it is very easy to do and she believes it’s a fast money source. That’s why she will use all of her $300 loan to buy the ingredients needed for her existing business. She is hoping to get another loan to extend it, and use it to build a house for her business so that she can sell her grilled foods and other things such pop-corn, chips and drinks. She is working very hard on her business in order to make money to sustain her family and kids

loans.use: Buying meats for the business.

loans.name: Toetu

texts.en: Toetu K. is currently 59 years old, and has nine children. She chose to make pancakes because it is easy for her to do. The other problem she faced is that her children have left to start their own families, and only her husband and she remain. She needed a source for additional profit, and turned to making pancakes. Her first loan was used to purchase flour, dripping, and sugar, all of which are necessary ingredients for pancakes. She hope she can get another loan to ensure her profit from her business.

loans.use: Buying ingredients for the business.

loans.name: Senara

texts.en: Senara P. is currently 30 years old, and has four children. She is experienced in making pork buns, a skill she learned from her mother. She decided to turn her expertise to a business, and used her first loan to purchase the necessary ingredients. In addition, she is also making ice-cakes. Senara is currently working extremely hard, because she believes that if she does not, she will not be able to earn a profit. She is extremely grateful for the program, and would like an additional loan to improve not only her business but also her home.

loans.use: Provide the needed ingredients for the business.

loans.name: Seia

texts.en: Seia A. is 55 years old, and has eleven children. Her burdens have now become slightly ligher as some of her children are overseas, and some have started their own families. However, she still needs money to support her own needs and her domestic commitments. She chose cooking pancakes as her business as she can make them with ease. She has spent her first loan of $300 to purchase the materials necessary to start her business. She has used the profits of her business to pay for the education of her youngest daughter’s school fees. She is extremely appreciative of the help she has received thus far.

loans.use: Buying ingredients for the pancakes business.

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta is a forty two year old married mother with four children. She is very good at cooking barbecued foods because she has worked in a restaurant in the town. She is now staying home and trying to start her own barbecue stand. She spent her $300 loan to buy all the needed ingredients for her business. She said that the profits she can get from her business are used to support her three children in school and provided food for the whole family. She is hoping to get another loan to make the business more profitable and help in paying her children's’ school fees. She really appreciates the help from SPBD and Kiva.

loans.use: Buying meats for the barbeque business.

loans.name: Talialofa

texts.en: Talialofa is a fifty seven year old lady with four children. She believes that a barbecue stand is the fastest way to earn money even though it requires more work before it can sell. But that doesn’t matter to her because she needs money to satisfy her family needs, especially to support her kids' education. She has applied for a $300 loan and will use it to buy all the ingredients needed for the barbecue business, especially meats. She is planning to get another loan to make her business bigger, maintain the good service she put in her business and get a hold on her usual customers. She is very excited for her business and appreciates the help she gets from Kiva.

loans.use: Buying ingredients needed for the business.

loans.name: Sarai

texts.en: Mrs. L. is 42 years old and the mother of three children. Her specialty is baking pies, cakes, scorns, donuts, German buns and sausage rolls. She currently supplies baked goods to shops. Sometimes she bakes for weddings and birthdays. Mrs. L. used her first $300 loan to purchase good baking ingredients for her business so she can maintain a high quality and continue to sell tasty goods. She is looking forward to getting another loan so she can build a special house for her baking business. Not only will she do her baking there, but she will also use it to start her own shop. She is very happy for her business and wishes to become perfect in the future.

loans.use: Provide ingredients for the baking business

loans.name: Taeletausia

texts.en: Taeletausia is a forty two year old woman with five children. She doesn't have a job and is now staying home to look after the children. That’s why she applied for the $300 loan to start her small business of selling ice-cake and pop-corn. Even though she sells these foods, she thinks that it is still not enough money to support her kids' education and sustain her family's needs. She is willing to get another loan to extend her business by adding a fast food stall to her current business. She is very happy for her business and she wishes to stay in it so that she can get more help through Kiva's loans.

loans.use: Buying ingredients for the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Millet processing machine

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.en:
I have some unfinished construction and I need to put on a concrete roof. It has been a bit difficult due to lack of money, but I am working a lot in order to get it and expand my house. I am asking for $900.00 dollars to put a concrete roof on my house.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo una construcción sin terminar y necesito poner techo de concreto, me ha sido un poco difícil por falta de dinero pero estoy trabajando mucho para lograrlo y ampliar más mi vivienda” Solicito $ 900.00 dlls para poner techo de concreto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Construction with Slabrock

loans.name: Donata

texts.en:
My children are growing up and I am seeing the need to expand my house a little in order to have more space and live more comfortably. I am asking for $800.00 dollars for the construction of a room in my house.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi hijos están creciendo y me veo en la necesidad de ampliar un poco mi casa para asi poder tener más espacio y vivir más comodamente” Solicito $ 800.00 dlls para la construcción de un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Construction of a room

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more charcoal to increase her profits

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Mrs. Catherine K. is a married  woman of  four children. She produces  and sells the local childrens' and students'   favourite, a porridge called "AKASSA".  She is requesting a loan to buy more ingredients and materials  to  enable her to make more  AKASSA. She is requesting  300 dollars. With that amount, she will be able to increase  her business, make a profit and be able to reimburse that amount within  12 months
She is  a member  of  a HELP Africa Women group called Patience. 

  .

loans.use: To process cereals such as millet or maize and make local poridge called  AKASSA

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
I have construction being done that I have not been able to finish due to lack of money, but now I would like to finish it once and for all as the current space is too small and uncomfortable for my family of six. Also, I would like to put in a bathroom. I am asking for $500.00 to finish the construction and put in a bathroom.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Pendleton, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo una construcción que no he podido terminar por falta de dinero pero ahora me gustaría terminarla ya que el espacio es muy reducido para mi familia y también muy incomodo debido a que somos 6 de familia además me gustaria poner un baño” Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para terminar mi construcción y poner el baño.

loans.use: Construction of bathroom and two rooms

loans.name: Nlhil

texts.en: Mrs. Nhil H. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is an open-air vendor selling fish to the people in her area, while her husband works as a fisherman. Together, they typically earn up to $20/day in revenue. Mrs. Nhil H. has to get up very early in morning to purchase fish from a fishery. Currently, she needs a motorcycle,primarily to be used for her business transportation. However, she faces financial constraints Therefore, she has recently applied for a loan to help her purchase a motorcycle to facilitate her business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to assist in her business.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Mrs. Lim N., 55, lives with her husband and one child in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband run a small stall selling pickled radish and beans to the people in her area, where together they can typically make around $6 each day. This couple is humbly requesting for a loan to purchase radishes from someone’s plantation so that they will resell them at a very good price.

loans.use: To purchase radishes from someone’s plantation so that they can resell them at a very good price.

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im R. is a 49-year-old mother of five children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To supplement her household, she and three of her children work in their plot of farmland growing and selling sugar cane plants and cucumber which enables them to generate about $5.80 each day. Her husband, meanwhile, works as a construction worker and the rest of her children attend school. Mrs. Im R. has recently applied for a loan to purchase another plot of land to expand her crop that she expects to make additional profits for her household.

loans.use: To purchase another piece of land to expand her crop that she expects to make additional profits for her household.

loans.name: Thou

texts.en: Mrs. Thou Pheap is 37 years old, a mother of three children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband operate a business either collecting or buying recyclable items from everywhere in their community. They then resell them to a nearby recycling plant, which enables them to generate on average up to $8 each day. This couple is humbly requesting for a loan to purchase a motorcycle in order to facilitate their business further  and make it faster, easier and more effective.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle in order to facilitate their business.

loans.name: Miatin

texts.id:
As a widow, Miatin has to work for her own living since all of her children are married and live with their own family. Before her husband passed away, Miatin had been selling meatball-noodle in a mobile food stall. After his husband passed away, no one could hep her to carry her food stall around. Miatin switched to a stationary food stall near the harbor. She opens her stall from 8AM to 9PM. With initial capital of 300,000 IDR (1USD~9,000 IDR), Miatin can earn a profit of 40,000 IDR daily. She used the profit to pay for her basic needs, for additional working capital and for paying the rent for her food stall of 150,000 IDR per month. With the loan from Dinari, Miatin plans to add more variety to her food stall so she can earn bigger profir and serves more customers.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Sebagai seorang janda, Miatin harus berusaha untuk menghidupi dirinya sendiri karena semua anaknya sudah menikah dan tinggal bersama pasangannya masing – masing. Sebelum suaminya meninggal, Miatin berjualan bakso dengan cara keliling di lingkungannya. Namun, setelah suaminya meninggal, tidak ada lagi yang bisa mendorong rombong yang dipakainya berjualan. Karena hal itu, Miatin beralih usaha dengan membuka usaha warung nasi di dekat pelabuhan. Miatin membuka usahanya dari pukul 8 pagi sampai pukul 9 malam. Dengan modal awal sebesar Rp. 300.000.-, Miatin bisa mendapat keuntungan Rp. 40.000.- per hari. Dengan keuntungan itu Miatin sisihkan untuk keperluan sehari – hari, menambah modal dan juga untuk membayar sewa tempat usaha sebesar Rp. 150.000.- per bulan. Dengan pinjaman dari Dinari, Miatin berencana untuk menambah jenis dagangannya sehingga ia bisa mendapat keuntungan yang lebih besar dan melayani lebih banyak pelanggan.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and ingredients for her food stall

loans.name: Khan

texts.en: Mrs. Khan S. M. is 26 years old, a mother of two children, and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on her farmland growing crop, earning around $6 each day .and two of her children attend school. Eventually, this couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a grinding machine to assist in grinding their crop faster, easier and more efficiently.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Teab

texts.en: Mrs.Teab S. is 26 years old, a mother of three children ,and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a vendor selling palm sugar (sugar made from palm juice) at a busy market where she  earns around $4 each day. Her husband  is a motor-taxi driver and two of her children attend school. Mrs. Teab S. hopes the loan will help her purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a business (a motor-taxi)

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Teab Sina has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Akhtar Mohammad

texts.en: Akhtar Mohammad lives in district 11 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is single and he is also studying at the university. He has a shoe shop where he works part-time. He wants to enlarge his shop, so he wants to take an individual loan to increase his stock to attract more clients. He wants to make a good future for himself and support his family. He is happy that he can expand his business.

loans.use: To increase his stock.

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 37 years old and has two children. Both of them are in school. He has a small general store in the middle of Kirkuk. He applied to borrow $1200 in order to purchase new goods for the store. He wants to develop his business and increase his income to save money and create a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new goods for the store

loans.name: Hidayet

texts.en: Hidayet is an Internally Displaced Person from the Gubadli district .He is married, has 2 children. He started his business in 2004. His business is located in front of his hostel. He has applied for his first loan and wants to borrow 700$ from Normicro. He wants to buy a fridge for his business to store inventory. He believes by buying this asset he will drammatically improve his business turnover.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Majeedan

texts.en: My husband and I work hard to provide for our four children. We work side-by-side selling fruits and vegetables. While he has a fruit cart, I sell ginger and garlic. We buy our stock from the wholesale market and make a small profit selling it in a busy up-scale area. However, at the end of the day this is not enough to sustain our family of six. We are hoping to expand our business and thereby increase our income by introducing more vegetables. We need a loan of $325.

loans.use: To expand our vegetable business

loans.name: Balqees

texts.en: I have been embroidering since my teens. When I got married, I decided to put my skills to some use so that I could help my husband with the household expenses. I started embroidering and stitching clothes on order, making a decent profit. I am now able to send three of my four children to school. I am looking to expand my business by using different materials and embellishments. I need a loan of $250 to buy the materials.

loans.use: Needs to buy raw material for her business

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mr. Uk T. is a 59 year old man who earns $2 a day working as a Khmer traditional doctor. His wife earns $10  a day selling fruit to people in her community. Between them they have 3 children, one of whom helps to sell the fruit and the other 2 are students. Mr Uk T. has applied for this loan so that his wife can increase her fruit stock and therefore more effectively meet customer demand. In the future she intends to see this business grow.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit for his wife's inventory

loans.name: Safia

texts.en: Last year my husband and I took out a loan and bought a modeling machine with which we started our business of making plastic spools. We sell the spools to kite shops and make a decent profit. Working with us, our two sons have learnt how to use the machine. We need a loan of $325 to purchase another modeling machine so that we can be even more productive and thereby increase our income.

loans.use: To buy a modeling machine to make plastic spools for kites.

loans.name: Chim

texts.en: Mrs. Chim C. L. is a 27-year-old mother of two little children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To cover he family’s expenses, she and her husband work making mortars and pestles and they then sell them to a retailer shop, from which they generate on average $4 each day.  Mrs. Chim C. is humbly requesting for a loan to purchase raw materials (rock) to keep running their business.

loans.use: To purchase raw material to produce mortars and pestles

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Chim Chhun Lim has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. S. V. Touch, 34, lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. Her husband earns $1 a day as a soldier, whilst she earns some extra money selling fruit at the local market. Between them they have 2 children who are both students. S. V. Touch is applying for this loan so that she can purchase more fruit in order to more effectively meet clients demand. She would also like to branch out into selling soft drinks.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit and soft drinks in order to meet her clients' needs.

loans.name: Riffat

texts.en: Four years ago, I took out a loan to start a family restaurant. After the first year of business, we had made a sizeable profit. The following three years we took out more loans to improve and expand our business. The profit we make has been progressively increasing and last year I was able to arrange my daughter’s wedding without having to worry about the costs. I now want to take out a loan of $425 to further expand my restaurant.

loans.use: Expand the existing resturant business

loans.name: Araz

texts.en: Mr Araz is a low income vulnerable person. He is 29 and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.Araz rents a butcher shop in the local bazaar of Saatli town. Every morning he goes  to villages to buy cattle and sheep. Then he sells meat in the bazaar. The working day lasts  until 2 o'clock. "I wish I had more money to buy more animals and sell them till evening. This would allow me to generate a higher income", he says. Araz needs a higher income to save money to fund his marriage.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs.Sok V. is a 48 year old housewife. Her husband works on their plot of farmland, growing bananas and other crops. They are applying for this $500 in order to purchase a cow to pull the plough to work the land. Doing this by hand has become too arduous.

loans.use: to purchase a cow to work in her farm

loans.name: Basheeran

texts.en: Last year I took out a loan with which I set up a grocery store and had three iron carts made. My family and I load the carts with fruit and vegetables and hire people on a daily-wage basis to manage the sales.  I, along with four of my children, run the grocery store. The income from these two ventures is just enough to meet the cost of living and send my youngest to school. I would like a loan of $300 to add more products to my grocery store and get two more carts made. That way our income will increase and we will be able to live better.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her store

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Akif is an Internally Displaced Person from the Fizuli region of Azerbaijan. He fled to Baku in 1993 together with his family consisting of his wife and three children. He started his business in 2001. He took four loans from the Normicro Baku office during 2003-2007. The purpose of his last loan is to buy small equipment such as tables and chairs for his cafe.

loans.use: To buy table and chairs

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is a widow with one daughter. She lives in Melitopol in south central Ukraine. Marina sells women’s footwear in the central market. Her vending kiosk has a favorable location at the market.

Marina believes her business has benefited much from loans through Nadiya Ukraine. Her business has grown a lot in the past five years that she has been in this trade. Presently, Marina’s gross income is about $1000 a month. She has about $1400 in inventory. Her monthly net profit is about $400.

Marina is a successful entrepreneur and a caring mother. She always finds time for her daughter. Marina’s primary goal is to help her daughter get a good job and a stable source of income as she enters a new phase of life.

Today Marina is requesting a loan to increase her inventory. We believe Marina’s optimism, determination and will-power will help her continue to be successful and make her dreams come true.

loans.use: To increase her inventory for next season

loans.name: Sulduz

texts.en: Mr. Sulduz is a low income vulnerable person. He is 43, married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli town in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in Caucasus region. Sulduz has taken on a lease for a  butcher shop, which is in the local bazaar. Each day he goes to  the villages surrounding Saatli  to buy animals. Then he sells meat in his shop. He works until 2 o'clock. " I wish I had more money to buy more animals to sell. It would allow me to provide  the necessities of life for my children." Now Sulduz has applied for a $500 loan to the Normicro Saatli branch and is waiting.

loans.use: To expand volume of business

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married with two daughters. She lives in Drogobych, Ukraine. Mariya runs a small business selling leather bags for men and women. She has been in this business for 9 years. Currently, Mariya has about $1400 in inventory. Her monthly business income is about $3600 and her net profit is around $500 a month.

Mariya is very communicative and sociable and has been an excellent client with Nadiya Ukraine. She has an outstanding credit history with not a single late loan payment. Each of her loans has been fully repaid on time.

Mariya’s elder daughter is a student at the Kiev Art Academy. Mariya helps her daughter and pays for her college. Mariya is requesting a loan of $600 to expand her business and purchase assorted new inventory. She believes this will help her generate additional profits and provide enough to help her daughters become established in life.

loans.use: To re-stock inventory

loans.name: Tim

texts.en: Mrs. Tim S. E. is a 50-year-old mother of three children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on a farmland growing a variety of vegetable s-- earning around $3.20 each day. Two of her children work at a garment factory, together earning around $150 each month and the rest of  them work as grocers in another city. This loan is primarily to be used to purchase more seeds for their farm but also to buy more grocery items for one of her children to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds for her farm and grocery items for one of her children to expand her inventory.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: I have been stitching clothes on order from the women of the neighborhood for a long time and my husband sells fruit from a fruit cart. We both work extremely hard just to meet our expenses and send our children to school. My husband now wants to introduce a larger variety of fruits to his cart so that he may get more business. Hopefully, this will increase our income and let us better our financially downtrodden state. We need a loan of $200.

loans.use: Wants to expand her husband's fruit cart business

loans.name: Najma

texts.en: I am Najma S. and I have 25 years of experience in making plastic flower bouquets. After my husband’s death, this has been our only source of income, which provides for my family. My two sons and their wives also help me in this business. Over the past four years, I have taken out loans to purchase larger amounts of flowers and have been making progressively better profits each time.  However, the income we earn is still not enough to send our grandchildren to school.  With my sons and daughters-in-law helping me, I would like to further expand my productivity and hence need a loan of $325 to purchase more raw materials.

loans.use: To expand her business in order to earn more money to send her grandchildren to school

loans.name: Nov Kim

texts.en: Mrs. Kim T. Nov is 31, a wife, and a mother of 4. Kim T. herself earns $3.60 a day selling beef soup. Her husband, 31, adds $2.50 to the family's income working as a moto-taxi driver. Kim T. has applied for this loan in order to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband. Furthermore, she would like to buy more utensils for her own business.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle and some cooking utensils.

loans.name: Noshi

texts.en: My husband and I have been making plastic flower bouquets for several years, which we sell in Lahore and other cities. In the past, we took out loans which successfully helped increase our income. However, our present income is still not sufficient for us to educate all our children. Two of our three children are not of school-going age yet, but when they are, we would like them to get  education like their elder brother. We are trying to grow our business so that we can educate and make our children better citizens.  We need a loan of $325.

loans.use: To expand  our plastic flower bouquet business

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en: Mr. Yashar is a low income vulnerable person. He is 43, married with three children and lives in the village of Saatli in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in  the Caucasus region. Yashar has taken on a lease for a small place in the local bazaar in Saatli . He sells clothes and shoes, but turnover is not so big as it could be. To increase his sales he would like to rent a mini shop and fill it up with consumer goods. That's why Yashar applied for $500 to the Normicro Saatli branch.

loans.use: To increase the variety of businesses

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Mrs. Long N. is 57 years old and lives with her husband and six children in Kampong Cham, province, Cambodia. She is a street-vendor who sells fermented fish. She earns about $2.50 a day. Her husband works as a policeman and earns about $2 each day.

Mrs. Long Neky is humbly requesting a loan for $400 to open a small grocery store that several of her children can operate. She hopes this new grocery store will enable her and her family to generate more income.

loans.use: Open a small grocery store to increase the family income

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Long Naiky has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: I am Nasreen S. and I run a family business making bouquets of plastic flowers. My son purchases the required materials from a warehouse in a nearby town, and my two daughters and I make the bouquets. My husband sells the bouquets on a cart in a commercial area of the city. We have managed to somehow increase our income and grow our business, but it still has a long way to go. Therefore, I need a loan of $325  to develop my business further.

loans.use: To expand her business of making plastic flower bouquets

loans.name: Heang Chai

texts.en:
Mrs. Heang Chai L. is 37 years old, married, with 4 children. Heang Chai L. earns $1.80 a day working at a garment factory. Her husband adds to the family's income by working as a motor-taxi driver; he can make $4-$5 a day.

Heang Chai L. intends to use this loan to buy pigs to breed and build a barn for them. She expects that this endeavor will increase the family's income and improve their quality of life.

loans.use: Purchase pigs and build a barn

loans.name: Riffat

texts.en: I learnt how to tailor but could not engage in it as a profession after my marriage. My husband used to be the only one providing for our family of six. However, last year I took out a loan and started a tailoring business so that I could add to my husband's earnings and support my family. With the money I earned I put all four of my children in school. I am managing very hard to make ends meet but still worry about paying the school fees and meeting my children's other needs. I therefore am requesting a loan of $300 with which to expand my tailoring business.

loans.use: Wants to expand her tailoring business

loans.name: Kaneez

texts.en: I sell garlic and ginger in my local vegetable market and my husband sells coconuts on his cart. We earn just enough to support our family. Moreover, for a long time I have wanted to expand the business by building my own vegetable shop, where my children can assist me. I need $250 to buy a large amount of  vegetables so that I can generate good profits and provide enough food and clothing for my family.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Herlin Wahyuliatini

texts.id:
Herlin owns a small snack stall in the Gilimanuk harbour. Living in her bare minimum house does not discourage her to earn a good living. Herlin has a four year old child and a husband who works as an informal ticket agent in the harbour. With a working capital of 100,000 IDR (1USD~9,000 IDR) Herlin purchase merchandise items in the Gilimanuk market and start selling from 4PM to 2AM, so she could still take care of her family while preparing her merchandise in the following morning. With her own capital, Herlin could earn a profit of 25,000 IDR per day. She kept some of the profit for additional capital and for saving. The loan from DINARI is going to be used to increase her merchandising items so she could gain more profit for her family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Herlin mempunyai usaha sebagai Dagang Asongan ( Menjual aneka snack dan minuman ) di pelabuhan Gilimanuk. Rumahnya yang sederhana dengan dinding batako dan lantai semen tidak membuat Herlin putus asa namun Ia tetap semangat. Herlin mempunyai seorang anak yang berusia 4 tahun dan suaminya bekerja sebagai calo tiket di pelabuhan. Dengan modal sebesar Rp. 100.000.-, Herlin akan membeli barang dagangannya di pasar pagi Gilimanuk dan mulai berjualan pukul 4 sore sampai pukul 2 pagi, sehingga di pagi hari ia bisa mengurus keluarga sambil menyiapkan dagangannya. Dengan modal yang dimilikinya, Herlin mampu mendapat keuntungan Rp. 25.000.- per hari. Keuntungan itu ia sisihkan untuk modal dan juga untuk tabungan. Pinjaman dari DINARI direncanakan untuk menambah barang dagangannya sehingga Herlin bisa mendapat keuntungan yang lebih besar untuk kesejahteraan keluarganya

loans.use: To purchase merchandising items such as cigarettes, instant noodles, kleenex, candies, beverages, etc

loans.name: Rukkaya

texts.en: I have six children. Five of them attend school and the youngest will also attend when he is old enough. My husband and I sell ginger and garlic in the local market. With the arrival of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan and Eid right around the corner, we would like to set up a fruit stall along with our current business, because the sale of fruits significantly increases during this month. We hope to make a sizeable profit out of this venture. We need a loan of $200 to set up the fruit stall and gather some stock of ginger and garlic as it is cheap this season.

loans.use: To set up a fruit stall

loans.name: Kulsoom

texts.en: I have five children: three daughters and two sons. My husband buys vegetables from a wholesale market and then we both sell them in neighborhood market. We have yet to attain a steady income because with each passing day, our daily expenses are increasing. We hope to increase our business so that we can better our financial condition. We seek a loan of $175 to expand our vegetable-selling business.

loans.use: To expand her family's vegetable selling business

loans.name: San

texts.en:
In the provinces of Cambodia, people rent sound systems (speakers and microphones) when they hold celebrations. Mrs. C. San's husband earns $5 a day renting sound systems to people in their community.

Mrs. C. San would like to use this loan to purchase another sound system - speakers and a microphone - to increase her husband's business.

Mrs. C. San is 32 years old, married, and has 3 children. She currently earns $3.70 a day working as a tailor.

loans.use: Purchase speakers and a microphone

loans.name: Sughrahi

texts.en: I am a mother of three. I sell ginger and garlic while my husband drives a rickshaw (local three-wheeled taxi). The income from these two sources is in very short supply and is barely enough to keep our businesses going and sustain us. However, his rickshaw needs a repair as its condition is deteriorating and for this, we need a loan. We need $175 for the maintenance works of the rickshaw.

loans.use: Maintainence of rickshaw

loans.name: Rahiba

texts.en:
Ms. Rahiba S. is a low-income, vulnerable person. She is 45, married with three children, and lives in the village of Saatli in the south-central plains area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Rahiba is leasing a small shop in Saatli. She sells jewellery and is looking for investors so that she can diversify her assortment. For this purpose she has applied to Normicro's Saatli branch to get a US$ 500 loan. Using this additional business capital, she believes that she can raise her monthly income from her shop by up to 30%.

loans.use: To increase the diversity of her inventory

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha T., 38, earns $2.50 a day selling vegetables. Her husband is a teacher, who earns $2 a day. She has 5 children; 3 are students and 2 work in the garment factory.

She is applying for this loan so that she can buy a motorcycle for her husband to enable him to become a taxi driver when he is not busy teaching. She intends to use the remainder of the money to renovate her house, which has fallen into disrepair.

loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle for her husband.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Chantha Touch has fully repaid this Kiva loan early.

Thank you for your support of Cambodian entrepreneurs. Lenders like you allow entrepreneurs around the world access to low-interest loans to finance their small businesses and support their families.

We hope you will continue your support by reinvesting in another Kiva entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Samina

texts.en: I am Samina S., and my husband and I are flower bouquet makers. We both love the work we do and do it with great zeal. Earlier on I took out some loans, which enabled me to construct a house of my own on the piece of land I had bought with my savings. I now want to expand my business and so require a loan of $300. Your loan can help me to provide much better clothing and food for my family.

loans.use: To expand her flower bouquet making business

loans.name: Zohra

texts.en: I operate a fruit and vegetable cart in an upscale neighborhood with my husband. I am the mother of six but I am only able to send two of my children to school. I am uneducated but I want to have a good future for all my children. I therefore need to expand our business and need a loan of $200 to buy more goods.

loans.use: Expand fresh fruit and vegetable business.

loans.name: Savoth

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Savoth, 49, lives with her husband, 55, in the Kampong Cham province of Cambodia. Savoth N. and her husband are farmers and earn $4 a day growing bananas and other crops. They have 6 children; 2 children are garment workers, 1 is a taxi driver, and the other 3 are students.

N. Savoth would like this loan buy a horse so that they can transport their crops to market. She would also like to purchase a motorcycle for the family's own transportation because hiring motor-taxis is too expensive.

loans.use: Purchase a horse to transport crops to the market

loans.name: Akhter

texts.en: I am the mother of four sons and all of them go to school. My husband, S., and I both sell vegetables and fruits on a cart in our neighboring town. Our sales are good, but they are not enough to support a family of six. Now we wish to get a separate cart and introduce a variety of seasonal fruits, as they are well in demand and generate good profits. Your loan can help me to increase my income and therefore let my children complete their education. I need a loan of $225.

loans.use: Buy a cart for fruit and expand our business.

loans.name: Isaq

texts.en:
Isaq is a low-income, vulnerable person. He is 45, married with two children, and lives in the village of Saatli, in the south-central plains area of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region.

Isaq owns a little shop where he sells spare parts. Every week Isaq goes to the wholesale market in the capital, Baku, to buy spare parts at reasonable prices. His son helps him and works as a shop assistant. (Isaq's son is the gentleman shown in the picture.)

Business is quite going well but Isaq needs more capital to develop his micro-business. For this purpose he has applied to Normicro's Saatli branch for a US$ 500 loan. Using this additional capital, he feels sure that he can raise his monthly income from his shop by up to 30%.

loans.use: To increase the variety of his inventory

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: I am Parveen A. and I have two children. Both of them go to school. I require a loan to expand my business of selling fruits on a cart. My husband also helps me in this business .The income from this expansion will let us continue to put food on our table and continue the studies of our daughters. I need a loan of $325.

loans.use: Expand the fruit business and buy a new cart.

loans.name: Usma

texts.en: I was married only a year ago. I manufacture zippers and sell them in a local market and my husband has a donkey cart that he uses to transfer goods from one place to another on order. The income from these ventures is just enough for us to live on. We plan to get another donkey cart, which we will rent out to increase our income. We both are not educated but we hope that same fate does not befall our children, who have yet to come in to this world. I need $175 to buy a new donkey cart.

loans.use: Buy another donkey cart.

loans.name: Khin

texts.en:
Mrs. Khin K., 25, lives with her husband, 28, in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia with their 2 children. She earns $3.60 a day breeding pigs and also works at the grinding mill.

Her husband adds $4 to the family's earnings by working as a mechanic. He buys broken motorcycles, fixes them, and then resells them.

Khin K. has applied for this loan so that her husband can purchase more spare parts for this business. She would also like to purchase more pigs to breed, to add to their family's income. ( her husband pictured here because Khin K. is unavailable)

loans.use: Spare parts for motorbikes

loans.name: Umi Prihatini

texts.id:
Umi Prihatini has to work extra hard to support her three children, especially as two of her children has grown up and need a lot more education fee. The income from her husband is not enough to cover the daily expenses and the children's education fee. Umi spends about $2 for the daily expenses only, not including the school fee and stipend for her children. DINARI will use the loan from DINARI to add more merchandise varieties so that the customers have more choices. She starts traveling to sell the merchandise from 8 am to 3 am the next day and she can increase her profit from $5 per day to $10 per day.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Untuk menghidupi ketiga orang anaknya Umi Prihatini terus bekerja tanpa mengenal rasa lelah, apalagi dua anaknya yang beranjak dewasa membutuhkan biaya pendidikan yang tidak sedikit. Penghasilan dari suaminyapun tidak mampu mencukupi pengeluaran biaya hidup dan biaya sekolah anak-anaknya. Setiapharinya Umi mengeluarkan biaya sebesar 20.000 rupiah untuk kelangsungan hidup mereka belum termasuk uang sekolah dan uang jajan untuk anak-anak. Dengan modal yang didapatkan dari DINARI Umi akan menambah jenis dagangannya sehingga para pembeli mempunyai banyak pilihan. Umi mulai menjajakan jualannya dari pukul 08.00 pagi sampai pukul 03.00 subuh, dan dari 50.000 rupiah keuntungan yang didapat perharinya bisa meningkat sampai 100.000 rupiah.

loans.use: To purchase various snacks, beverages, etc

loans.name: Erkin

texts.en:
R. Erkin has been engaged in business for 7 years. She has 3 children. Her business is trade of office supplies and is located in Gafurov, Khujand, in the Farovon market. She became a client of MicroInvest in 2005. She is a responsible person and repays her loan on time.

She has a wide assortment of office supplies, and her business is going well. Presently it is school season, and she has good turnover of her stock. She buys her goods from Istaravshan, Khujand. She goes to purchase goods every week. In the future she wants to increase the volume of her goods. For this reason, she is requesting $1200.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Tabiah

texts.id:
Living as a widow doesn't discourage Tabiah to work hard to support her life. Her husband died from a sickness 5 years ago. Now she lives with her son, Supianto, a second-year STM (high school with specialization in technician work) student, in a very simple house with cement floor and bamboo wall. Tabiah starts traveling around to sell the merchandise from 5 pm to 2 am. In the morning, she prepares the merchandise to be sold while doing her house work. In the beginning, she had $32 as the initial capital and earned only very little profit of $1.6 per night. The profit also has to be spent for her daily expenses and her son's education. After she receives the loan from DINARI, she can improve her profit to $5 per night. With the increased profit, she can save a little of the profit now.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Hidup tanpa suami tidak menyurutkan semangat Tabiah untuk bekerja memenuhi kebutuhan hidupnya. Suaminya sudah meninggal 5 tahun yang lalu karena sakit. Sekarang dia tinggal dirumahnya yang sangat sederhana dengan lantai semen dan dinding gedek ditemani oleh seoranng anaknya , Supianto, yang sekarang duduk di bangku STM kelas 2. Tabiah menjajakan jualannya mulai pukul 5 sore sampai pukul 2 dini hari, sedangkan paginya ia melakukan persiapan untuk jualannya sambil mengerjakan pekerjaan rumah tangga. Awal mula Tabiah hanya bermodalkan Rp. 300.000.- dan hanya mendapat sedikit keuntungan yakni Rp. 15.000.- per malam. Keuntungan itu pun harus disisihkan untuk biaya hidup dan uang sekolah anaknya. Namun setelah mendapat pinjaman dari DINARI, Tabiah sudah mampu mengembangkan usahanya dengan menambah jumlah dagangannya sehingga Tabiah mampu meningkatkan keuntungannya menjadi Rp. 50.000.- semalam. Dengan keuntungan itu, kini Tabiah dapat menyisihkan sedikit dari keuntungannya untuk ditabung.

loans.use: To buy merchandises such as cigarettes, snacks, beverages, etc

loans.name: Zinnat

texts.en: Hoshimova Zinnat has been our client since 2002. Her business is trade of vegetables. She is married and has 5 children. Her husband is her business partner, and he sells vegetables in the market with her. (He is in the photo). Their stall is located in Chkalovsk, Khujand. They buy their products from Panjshanbe every week. Her elder son helps to transport the vegetables from Panjshanbe to their business place. Today their business is going well. In the future they want to rent one more trade place for their son. To do this, they need a loan of $1000.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Mrs. Eunice O., 54 years old, married, and mother of six children, sells provisions and drinks to people in her area. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Eunice has been in this business for 6 years and hopes to increase her business capital and thus her inventory with the loan of US$ 550 which will permit her to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provisions and drinks for resale

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suardani

texts.id:
Mrs. Ketut Suardani's business is the rearing of two sows. She is 32 years old and has been breeding pigs since the year 2000. Mrs. Ketut Suardani makes time to go to their stall every day, 2 hours in the morning, 2 hours in the early afternoon, and 2 hours in the late afternoon. She starts by feeding the pigs, cleaning their stalls, and finally nursing the piglets. With two sows, Mrs. Ketut Suardani can produce 40 piglets in one year. One piglet sells for 150,000 Rupiah. Gross proceeds can approach as high as six million rupiah per year. Even though her room is very simple, it is her own. Mrs. Ketut Suardanai lives together with her husband and two children. The loan from Dinari will be used to add to her livestock rearing business, adding one sow.

Translated from Indonesian by Andrew Goss, Kiva Volunteer.

Memelihara 2 induk babi merupakan usaha Ibu Ketut Suardani. Ibu yang berusia 32 tahun ini mulai beternak babi lokal sejak tahun 2000. Ibu Ketut Suardani meluangkan waktunya setiap hari 2 jam di pagi hari, 2 jam disiang hari dan 2 jam lagi pada sore hari dikandang babinya. Mulai dari memberi makan babi, membersihkan kandang hingga merawat anak babi. Dengan 2 ekor induk babi Ibu Ketut Suardani bisa memproduksi 40 ekor anak ( bibit ) dalam satu tahunnya. Satu ekor bibit babi dijual Rp.150.000,-. Keuntungan kotor bisa didapatkannya sebesar Rp. 6.000.000, pertahunnya. Meskipun rumahnya sederhana itu adalah rumahnya sendiri. Ibu Ketut Suardani tinggal bersama suaminya dan 2 orang anaknya. Pinjaman dari Dinari digunakan untuk menambah ternak peliharaannya berupa 1 ekor induk babi.

loans.use: Increase piglet litter - Menambah bibit penginduk

loans.name: Kurbon

texts.en: R. Kurbon has his own shop in Ckalovsk. He sells different kinds of goods from household goods to electrical goods, toys, towels and so on. He wants customers to be able to find all the goods they need. He has a lot of clients, and his shop is one of the known shops in the area. He is always friendly with clients, and they are satisfied with his service. His nephew helps him in his shop when he is on the trip to purchase goods. (He is in the photo). In the near future he wants to expand his business by including new household goods.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Musarat

texts.en: I started making zippers six years ago; my complete family helps me in this business except my youngest daughter, whom I have managed to send to school. I wish to send some of my other children to school as well, as it is never too late to study. I require a sum of $325 to help myself increase my income through making more zips. Please lend me the required amount.

loans.use: I want to manufacture more zippers.

loans.name: Amaka Ojinaka

texts.en:
"I hope to invest in my business," says Mrs. Amaka E.. She is 29 years old, married, and hails from Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells women's wear and cosmetics and rents VCDs to people in her area. She has been in this business since 2001.

Amaka is looking forward to receiving a loan in the amount of US$ 400 to buy more women's clothing, cosmetics, and VCDs.

loans.use: To buy women's clothing and cosmetics for sale and VCDs for rental in her boutique

loans.name: Chanthu

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthu T., 39 is married and has 4 children. She and her husband are farmers. Her husband makes an additional $2 a day as a motor-taxi driver.

They would like to use this loan to purchase a plot of land and a bamboo ladder so that they can climb palm trees to collect the sap to make into sugar.

loans.use: Purchase a plot of farm land and a ladder to start a sugar business.

loans.name: Saide

texts.en:
Saide is 35-year-old widow living with her mother in Laylaki (Beirut suburbs). She learned embroidery while she was still at school but starting doing business only 5 years ago. Her work is sold to a workshop in the Barbir region. In order to expand her business, Saide needs $300 to buy 5 tablecloths and all the required material for the embroidery of the latter.

Saide is part of a group with other women. The members of the group are self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rural areas. Group lending is based on incremental increase of the loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that is encourages the collaboration approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool towards economic empowerment for women.

loans.use: To buy necessary material for the embroidery work

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Mrs. Bun Sokunthear, 27, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband and 2 children. She currently earns $15 a day raising and selling ducks and chickens. Her husband is a mechanic and earns $3 a day.

Mrs. Sokunthear has applied for this loan so that she can purchase more ducks to raise and sell, and thus increase their income.

loans.use: Purchase more ducks

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Bun Sokhunthear has paid back this Kiva loan early.

Thank your for your support. Thanks to lenders like you, entrepreneurs around the world have access to low-interest loans to invest into their small businesses and families. We hope that you will continue your support  and reinvest your loan in another entrepreneur.

Sincerely,
Isadora Tang, Kiva Fellow, Cambodia

loans.name: Kubra

texts.en: I am Kubra A. and I want to help my husband to increase our fruit business that he does near the local university campus. Our present income is very small and we hardly manage our living. You can help me by lending $175, which we can invest in our business to increase our income.

loans.use: Expand the existing fruit business.

loans.name: Wafaa

texts.en:
Wafaa lives in Borj A. Barajneh with her parents and her siblings. Wafaa is selling clothes, towels, underwear, etc. to retail shops. "The money I earn is for tuition fees for my accounting studies." Wafaa is a 21-year-old woman striving for her education. She needs $300 to purchase enough merchandise for her business.

Wafaa is part of a group with other women. The group consists of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rurA. areas. Group lending is based on incrementA. increase of the loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that is encourages the collaboration approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool towards economic empowerment for women.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her business

loans.name: Lek

texts.en:
Mr. Lek C. D. is a 63-year-old widower who lives with his four children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver, and earns about $3 each day. One of his children works as a security guard, one is a motor-taxi driver, and another is a singer.

Mr. Lek C. D. has humbly applied for a loan to purchase a motorcycle to replace his old, ruined one, which often needs repairs.

loans.use: Purchase a replacement motorcycle for a taxi service.

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en: "I have more than 5 years of experience in my business and it is my greatest source of income. With it, I provide for my family," says Mrs. Abigail I., fashion designer. Abigail is 34 years old, married, with three children. She hopes to increase her output with the requested loan of US$ 400.

loans.use: To buy an additional sewing machine and material for sale

loans.name: Srun

texts.en:
Mrs. Srun T., 32, and her husband, 33, live together in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. Srun T. currently earns $4 a day selling fish, while her husband earns $2.50 a day as a motor-taxi driver.

Srun T. would like to set up another business selling clothes to people near the Thai border, for which she is borrowing $800.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Hyam

texts.en:
Hyam A. C. is a 38-year-old woman who makes hair extensions. She needs $400 to buy naturA. hair in order to make the extensions and then sell them to a wig producer. Hyam lives in Hay El Selloum, in the Beirut suburbs with her family. The profit she earns is used for her family's living expenses and to reinvest in her business.

Hyam is part of a group with other women. They are a group of self-chosen women, living in vulnerable conditions, mostly in rurA. areas. Group lending is based on incrementA. increase of loan amount and group solidarity to guarantee repayment. The strength of the group loan is that is encourages the collaboration approach in the borrowing community. The group loan is a very powerful tool towards economic empowerment for women.

loans.use: To buy natural hair to make the extensions

loans.name: Nkechi

texts.en: A woman who is proud of being a member of LAPO, Nkechi has a business that gives her and her family joy. Nkechi sells fairly-used electronics in her shop. She is 50 years old ,a widow, and mother of four children. She has been in this business for over 5 years and needs a loan of US$ 1,175 to boost her business and provide more easily for her family.

loans.use: To buy more fairly-used electronics for resale

loans.name: Sovann

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Sovann is 35 years old and lives with her husband and 4 children in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. C. Sovann stays at home to take care of her children.

Her husband currently earns $2 a day as a construction worker. He would like to purchase a motorcycle and a cart so that he may become a tuk-tuk driver. C. Sovann anticipates that he could earn an extra $3 a day to support the family.

loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle and a cart with which to operate a business

loans.name: Herlina

texts.id:
Herlina is a mother of two. In order to take care off her children and to add to the income of the family everyday, she has started selling food at a snack bar. She has diligently occupied herself with this work since before she was married, knowing how to cook many things. Herlina is very confident with her abilities. The borrowed capital which she would receive from DINARI will be used by Herlina to renovate her snackbar, aka the building, so that it can be bigger and the seating capacity will be greater. With her loan of 500,000 Rupiah, Herlina can earn 60,000 to 80,000 Rupiah in profit per day, and from those gains, Herlina will be able to add to the needs of her family every day, and also to the needs of her children's education.

Translated from Indonesian by Andrew Goss, Kiva Volunteer.

Herlina adalah ibu dari dua orang anak, untuk menghidupi anak-anaknya dan menambah perekonomian keluarga setiapharinya Ia berjualan Makanan dengan membuka warung makan. Usaha ini sudah ditekuninya sejak belum menikah maklum dalam hal masak-memasak Herlina sangat senang dengan bakatnya ini. Pinjaman modal yang diterima dari DINARI digunakan oleh Herlina untuk merenovasi warungnya alias rumahnya sehingga bisa lebih besar dan daya tampung pelanggan lebih banyak. Dengan modal 500.000 rupiah Herlina bisa meraup keuntungan 60.000 – 80.000 rupiah/harinya dan dari keuntungannya itu Herlina bisa memenuhi kebutuhan hidup keluarga setiapharinya dan juga kebutuhan pendidikan anak-anaknya.

loans.use: To renovate her food stand and buy cooking ingredients - untuk merenovasi warung makan dan membeli bahan makanan

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noun M. is a 50-year-old mother, who lives with her husband and 2 children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. To supplement her entire family's income, M. sells various kinds of fruit at an open-air market. She is able to earn an average of $10/day.

Her husband is a village chief, who earns $3/day. Mrs. Noun's children are students. Mrs. Noun has applied for a loan to purchase more fruit to meet the growing demands of her customers.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by adding more fruit to meet her clients' needs.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Noun Malai and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Ayu Nirwati

texts.id:
No free time left for Mrs Nirwati. This mother of 3 children is always full of activities. After finishing her job in the kitchen, she feeds the pigs. One female pig consumes a lot of her time, especially when it gives birth. One female pig, that costs about $75, can give birth 3 times a year. Once it gives birth, we can get 5 to 8 piglets. After breeding it for about 1 to 1.5 months, the piglets can be sold for $16 each. Mrs Nirwati has started this business for a few years. She plans to add 2 more female pigs when she gets enough fund.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Tidak ada waktu luang yang tersisa bagi Ibu Nirwati. Ibu dengan tiga orang anak ini selalu selalu beraktifitas. Setelah selesai didapur ia memberi makan ternak babi peliharaannya. Seekor induk babi bisa menghabiskan banyak waktunya, apalagi bila induk ini melahirkan anak. Induk babi yang dibelinya seharga Rp. 700.000,- ini dalam satu tahun bisa melahirkan sebanyak 3 kali. Sekali beranak bisa 5-8 ekor anak dilahirkan. Setelah dipelihara satu sampai satu setengah bulan anak babi ini bisa dijual Rp. 150.000,- perekor. Ibu Ayu Nirwati baru beberapa tahun mulai beternak babi, rencananya akan menambah 2 ekor induk babi lagi kalau sudah mempunyai dana yang cukup.

loans.use: Adding growing pigs

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Cheang Vathy, 49, lives with her husband, 62, and 3 children in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. Her husband is a carpenter and earns approximately $7 a day. Two of their children also work in this business, and the third works at the factory. 
 Mrs. Cheang Vathy has applied for this loan in order to purchase a motorcycle for her husband's business. The couple would like to have a motorcycle so they can  transport the goods further, faster, and more easily, and thus reach more customers and increase their profits.

( This is a picture of her husband because Vathy is unavailable)

loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle to transport goods

loans.name: Ni Wayan Wati

texts.id:
Mrs Wayan Wati, a 50-year-old lady, has had this pig farm business for quite some time. Her age is not a problem for her to develop her business. She started the business from 1 sow (female pig) and now she already has 16 pigs and 1 sow. She breeds the pigs in her own garden so that the pigs' feces can be utilized as fertilizer. She can harvest pigs 3 times a year. She earns $16 profit for each pig. In a year, she earns about $773 profit a month. She spends the income for her daily expense and her children education (1 child in high school and the other one in elementary school). The loan from Dinary is useful for adding 6 more pigs.

Translated from Indonesian by Kustini Lim, Kiva volunteer.

Bagi Ibu Wayan Wati usia yang semakin senja bukanlah halangan untuk mengembangkan usaha. Ibu yang berusia 50 tahun ini sudah lama mengembangkan usaha ternak babinya. Bermula dari 1 induk babi saja, tapi saat ini Ni Wayan Wati memelihara babi penggemukan sebanyak 16 ekor dan satu penginduk. Ibu Wayan Wati memelihara babi di kebunnya dengan alasan supaya kotorannya bisa dipakai pupuk. Dalam satu tahun Ni Wayan Wati bisa 3 kali panen. Dari satu ekor ternak bisa dapat untung Rp.150.000,-. Kalau dihitung dalam satu tahun ia mendapat keuntungan Rp.7.200.000,-. Ni Wayan Wati menggunakan uangnya untuk biaya hidup sehari-hari dan membiayai pendidikan sekolah anaknya yang duduk Sekolah Mengah Atas dan di Sekolah Dasar. Ni Wayan Wati bersyukur mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari yang ia gunakan menambah 6 ekor bibit untuk penggemukan

loans.use: Adding growing pigs

loans.name: Ni Kadek Ayu

texts.id:
It is very common for a Balinese woman to work as a farmer to supplement her family's income. Ni Kadek Ayu S. works as a pig farmer to help her husband who sells potted plants for a living. She started with 1 breeding pig that she bought for about $60 that gave birth to 5 piglets in 4 months. One month and a half later, these piglets were sold for $15 each. So Ni Kadek ayu S. earned $75. In one year, Ni Kadek Ayu S. managed to sell $225 worth of piglets, with net profit of $150. These earnings were used to supplement her family's income. Mrs. Kadek Ayu S. will use $140 loan from DINARI to buy more breeder pigs and repair their sty. She expects that with one more breeder pig, she can earn 2x what she earns currently.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva volunteer

Bagi perempuan Bali, pekerjaan sebagai petani atau peternak itu sudah umum. Hal ini dilakukan sebagai usaha sampingan untuk menambah pendapatan keluarga. Tidak cukup membantu suami sebagai penjual pot tanaman disela waktunya Ni Kadek Ayu S. juga mencoba usaha beternak babi. Mulai dari 1 ekor penginduk Ibu Ni Kadek Ayu S. mengawali usaha beternaknya. Induk babi yang Ni Kadek Ayu S. beli dengan harga Rp.600.000,- setelah empat bulan sudah melahirkan 5 ekor anak. Satu setengah bulan berikutnya anak babi ini dijual dengan harga Rp.150,000,- perekor. Jadi Ni Kadek Ayu S. mendapat uang Rp 750.000,-. Selama satu tahun Ni Kadek Ayu S. berhasil menjual bibit babi seharga Rp.2.250.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih kira-kira Rp. 1.500.000,-. Meskipun kecil beternak babi juga mendapatkan keuntungan tambahan. Ibu Kadek Ayu S. mendapat modal dari DINARI sebesar Rp.1.400.000,- yang digunakan untuk menambah induk babi dan memperbaiki kandangnya. Dengan tambahan 1 ekor induk babi lagi akan mendapat keuntungan 2 kali lipat dari semula

loans.use: Purchase more breeder pigs

loans.name: Niluh Sami

texts.id:
Usually a pig can be sold for about $40-50 each after three months growing. A farmer can usually harvest 3-4x a year. Mrs Luh Sami A. has worked 3 years as a pig farmer. At this time she has only 3 pigs, thus she feels that she has not maximized her earning potential. Mrs. Luh Sami A. plans to farm 5 to 7 pigs at a time to earn more. Piglets now cost her about $15-20 each.

Translated From Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Tiga bulan pemeliharaan maka babi siap dijual dengan harga perekor Rp. 400.000,- sampai Rp.500.000,- . Dalam satu tahun bisa panen 3-4 kali untuk babi gulingan . Ibu Luh Sami A. yang sudah tiga tahun memelihara babi gulingan ini merasakan ada hasil tambahan dari usaha ini. Masalah yang dihadapi saat ini ternak peliharaannya masih terlalu sedikit, baru 3 ekor. Ibu Luh Sami A. berencana memelihara ternak sampai 5 sampai 7 ekor supaya bisa mendapat hasil yang lebih. Harga bibit babi saat ini berkisar antara Rp.150.000,- s/d Rp.200.000,- / ekor.

loans.use: Adding grower pigs

loans.name: Ni Nengah Wentri

texts.id:
Mrs. Nengah Wentri owns a grower pig farm. Currently Mrs. Nengah Wentri farms 3 pigs. Each day she feeds her pigs for about 4 hours, morning, afternoon and evening. After four to five months, she can harvest her pigs for $40-$45 each. With $150 loan, Mrs. Nengah Wentri can earn $80 in profit. each month she can earn $20 to her income.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva volunteer

Ibu Nengah Wentri mempunyai usaha ternak babi penggemukan. Saat ini Ibu Nengah Wentri memelihara 3 ekor ternak babi. Setiap hari ia meluangkan waktunya untuk memberi makan babinya kira –kira 4 jam perhari dari pagi, siang dan sore. Empat sampai lima bulan babinya sudah bisa dipanen dengan harga berkisar Rp. 400.000,- s/d Rp. 450.000,-. Dengan modal 1.400.000,- selama 4 bulan Ibu Nengah Wentri bisa mendapatkan keuntungan Rp. 800.000,-. Setiap bulan ia bisa mendapat penghasilan Rp.200.000,- untuk tambahan biaya hidupnya.

loans.use: Adding Growing Pigs

loans.name: Kayode

texts.en: Mr. Koyode O. deals in video coverage and photography, etc. He hopes to buy an additional digital camera to enhance his business prospects. 38 years old, he is married with 2 children and has been in this business since 2000.

loans.use: To buy film and video coverage equipment for his business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret O., from Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria, is 32 years old and sells medicine to people living in her community. A LAPO member for 6 years, Margaret is married with 3 children. She is asking for a loan in the amount of US$ 400 to enable her to buy more medical drugs to sell in her little pharmacy.

loans.use: To buy more medicines for her little pharmacy

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Mrs. Eunice Osagie sells drinks and provisions in her little shop. She is 35 years old, married with two children, and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She needs US$ 400 for the expansion of her business. She has been in this business since 2005.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for sale

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Mrs. Doris O. is 41 years old, a married mother with 2 children. She started her beer parlour business in the year 1995 long before she came in contact with LAPO. Since 2003, she has also been a faithful LAPO member. She hopes to receive a loan in the amount of US$ 475 for the improvement of her business by expanding her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, food ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is a married fashion designer. Living in a semi-urban area of Edo State, Nigeria, she is 30 years of age, has one child, and has been a faithful LAPO member for the past 4 years . She is asking for a loan in the amount of US$ 475 to enable her to buy a sewing machine and other tailoring equipment for her business. She is a secretary in LAPO's union and has been in the dressmaking business since 2001.

loans.use: To buy an additional sewing machine and materials for dressmaking

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Miss Florence E. is 34 years old and is a trained hairdresser. She is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 325 to expand her business, selling ladies' wear, shoes, and bags as well as operating a beauty salon. She also needs another hair dryer to enable her to attend to more customers.

Florence has been a LAPO member for the past 2 years. She has been in business since 1993.

loans.use:
To buy an additional hair dryer, relaxers, shampoo, bags & 
shoes for sale

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Mrs. Mabel I. who sells lumber, wants a loan of US$ 400 so as to develop her micro-business. She is 35 years old, married with five children, and has been a trustworthy LAPO client for the past 5 years.

Mabel is a native of Bini and has been in this business since 2004. With the loan, she will be able to buy more lumber for sale.

loans.use: To buy more timber for resale

loans.name: Jane
